data.title: Television This Week
data.text:
“RIPPING YARNS” — Michael Palm of the Monty Python troupe stars in a new six‐part series parodying British manners and customs of the early 1900's, tonight at 10 on Channel 13.

Today

4 P.M. (2) “BLACK BEAUTY.” A rebroadcast of an hour‐long animated version of the Anna Sewell novel.

9 (4) “DOG DAY AFTERNOON.” The television premiere of the 1975 film based on an actual attempted bank robbery in New York City; starring Al Pacino.

Monday

9 P.M. (4) “THE OMEN.” The television premiere of the 1976 thriller film; starring Gregory Peck and Lee Remick.

Tuesday

8 P.M. (13) “CALL GOVERNOR BYRNE.” An hour‐long live telephone question-and-answer session with the Governor of New Jersey.

9 (2) “THE STREETS. OF L.A.” A twohour made-for-television film about middle‐aged divorced woman who embarks on a lone pursuit of a gang of teen‐aged vandals; starring Joanne Woodward.(See John J. O'Connor's essay on page 31.)

Wednesday

4 P.M. (7) “THE LATE GREAT ME: STORY OF A TEEN‐AGE ALCOHOLIC.” This 90‐minute television drama, part of the “Afterschool Specials” series, is about a 15-year-old girl's struggle with alcoholism; starring Maia Danziger.

8 (2) “ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT.” A new three‐hour made-fortelevision dramatization of Erich Maria Remarque's novel about young German artist's experiences as a soldier in World War I; starring Richard Thomas, Ernest Borgnine, Ian Holm, Donald Pleasence and Patricia Neal. (See David Lewin's article on page 31.)

8:30 (13) “LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER.” The Soviet pianist Emil Gilels will be the guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, with Zubin Mehta conducting; the program, which will include Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1, will be simulcast in stereo on WNCN‐FM.

Thursday

8 P.M. (4) “A BRIDGE TOO FAR.” The first half of a two‐part presentation of the 1977 film about the largest airborne assault in the history of warfare; starring Dick Bogarde, Michael Caine, Sean Connery, Elliot Gould, Gene Hackman, Anthony Hopkins, Laurence Olivier, Ryan O'Neal, Robert Redford, Maximilian Schell and Liv Ullmann. (Part II will be shown on Friday at 8 P.M.)

8:30 (2) “SILVER STREAK.” The television premiere of the 1976 film comedy set aboard a train from Los Angeles to Chicago; starring Gene Wilder, Jill Clayburgh and Richard Pryor.

9 (7) “THE FRENCH ATLANTIC AF- FAIR.” The first segment of a threepart presentation of a made-for-tele- vision thriller about the seizure of a luxury ocean liner by a cult leader and his followers; starring Chad Everett, Telly Savalas and Shelley Winters. (Parts II and HI will be shown Friday and Sunday evenings, respectively, at 9.)

Friday

10 P.M. (13) “MOUNTBATT'EN: A MAN FOR THE CENTURY.” The first hour‐long installment in an eightpart biographical documentary about Britain's late Lord Mountbatten.

Saturday

5 P.M. (5) “TREASURE ISLAND.” The television premiere of a 1972 film version of the Robert Louis Stevenson adventure story; starring Orson Welles.

9 (2) “SALEM'S LOT.” A two‐hour made-for-television horror film about vampires in modern New England; starring James Mason, David Soul, Lance Kerwin and Bonnie Bedelia.

Channel Information

Channel 2 (WCBS)

Channel 9 (WOR)

Channel 4 (WNBC)

Channel 11 (WPIX)

Channel 5 (WHEW)

Channel 13 (WHET)

Channel 7 (WABC)

Channel 31 (WNYC)

Complete evening schedules from 6 P.M. onward for the following UHF stations are included in each day's listings.

Channel 21 (WL1W)‐Garden City, L.I. Long Island Educational Council. School and PBS programs and Long Island news. Weekdays from 1 P.M., Saturday and Sunday from 3:30 P.M.

Channel 25 (WNYE)‐Board of Education. New York City School programs and public television repeats. Weekdays from 9 A.M., Saturday from 4 P.M., Sunday from 9 A.M.

Channel 41 (WXTV)—Paterson, N.J. Spanish films, serials, news, sports. Weekdays from 2 P.M., and Saturday and Sunday from II A.M

Channel 47 (WNJU)—Newark, N. J. Mostly serials and variety programs in Spanish and Italian. Weekdays from 4:30 P.M., Saturday from 2:30 P.M., Sunday from 2 P.M.

Channel 50 (WNJM)‐Little Falls, N.J. New Jersey Public . Broadcasting. Mostly local New Jersey news, Sports, PBS piograins.- Weekdays from 9 A.M., Saturday and Sunday from 5 P.M.

Channel 60, 68 (WWHT)—West Orange, N.J. Pay television after 8 P.M. Variety, children's, financial, ethnic and sports programs. Weekdays and Saturday from 7:15 A.M. and Sunday from 6:95 A.M.

Details received too late for this schedule are on the Weather Page in today's main news section.
